targets.expr: sum(rate(grpc_server_handled_total{job="content-service", cluster=~"$cluster", grpc_method=~"$grpc_method"}[1m])) by (grpc_code, grpc_method, cluster)
sum(rate(grpc_server_started_total{job="content-service", cluster=~"$cluster", grpc_method=~"$grpc_method"}[1m])) by (grpc_code, grpc_method, cluster)
sum(rate(grpc_server_handled_total{job="content-service", cluster=~"$cluster", grpc_method=~"$grpc_method"}[1m])) by (grpc_method, cluster)

sum(
    rate(grpc_server_handling_seconds_sum{job="content-service", cluster=~"$cluster", grpc_method="$grpc_method"}[5m])
  ) by (cluster, grpc_method)
  /
  sum(
    rate(grpc_server_handling_seconds_count{job="content-service", cluster=~"$cluster", grpc_method="$grpc_method"}[5m])
  ) by (cluster, grpc_method)
kube_pod_container_info{cluster=~"$cluster", pod=~"$pod", image=~".+", container="content-service"}

panels.description:
Saturation > 100% means that the container is requesting more than its limits.

Kubernetes will start to throttle CPU when that happens. That's a sign of degraded performance.

'No Data' indicates that the pod has no CPU limits.
panels.title: CPU Saturation

targets.expr: sum(container_memory_working_set_bytes{container!="POD", container!="", cluster=~"$cluster", node=~"$node", pod=~"$pod"}) by (pod, cluster, node)

panels.description:
Memory can't be throttled. When a container reaches 100% of its memory limits,  Kubernetes will kill the container and restart it.

'No Data' indicates that the pod doesn't have Memory limits.
panels.title: Memory Saturation

targets.expr: rate(kube_pod_container_status_restarts_total{cluster=~"$cluster", pod=~"$pod"}[1m])
kube_pod_container_status_running{cluster=~"$cluster", pod=~"$pod"} == 1
kube_deployment_spec_replicas{cluster=~"$cluster", deployment="content-service"}
kube_deployment_status_replicas_available{cluster=~"$cluster", deployment="content-service"}
kube_deployment_status_replicas_unavailable{cluster=~"$cluster", deployment="content-service"}
process_resident_memory_bytes{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"content-service"}

panels.title: Memory Usage (as seen by the runtime process)

targets.expr: rate(process_cpu_seconds_total{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"content-service"}[1m])

panels.title: CPU Usage (as seen by the runtime process)

targets.expr: go_memstats_heap_sys_bytes{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"content-service"}
rate(go_memstats_alloc_bytes_total{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"content-service"}[1m])
go_goroutines{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"content-service"}
go_gc_duration_seconds{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"content-service", quantile="0.5"}
go_gc_duration_seconds{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"content-service", quantile="0.75"}
go_gc_duration_seconds{cluster=~"$cluster", job=~"content-service", quantile="1"}
